Name: Goals
Formula: Count of events where event_type = 'shot' AND event_detail_1 = 'goal' for event_player_1.
FilterContext: Usually 5v5 or all strengths; filter by season, team, or game as needed.
Notes: Core scoring stat; combine with TOI and game state to interpret usage vs efficiency.
HowToRead: If a player has 2 goals in a game, they directly finished two scoring plays. Over a season, compare goals to shot volume and role (PP vs EV) to judge finishing ability.

Name: Primary Assists
Formula: Count of shot events with event_detail_1 = 'goal' AND play_details_1 = 'primary_assist' for the credited passer.
FilterContext: Same strength filters as goals; often split into EV and PP.
Notes: Captures the last pass before a goal; strong proxy for playmaking.
HowToRead: High primary assists means this player is often the one making the final pass that creates goals. Compare to secondary assists and shots to see if they drive offense as a passer or shooter.

Name: Secondary Assists
Formula: Count of shot events with event_detail_1 = 'goal' AND play_details_2 = 'secondary_assist'.
Notes: More context-dependent than primary assists; can benefit from bounces and chaos plays.
HowToRead: Secondary assists show involvement earlier in the play. A high number can still signal good puck movement and support, but is noisier than primary assists.

Name: Points
FilterContext: Interpret per TOI, per game, and by situation (EV, PP, PK).
Notes: Traditional counting stat; hides rate differences and deployment.
HowToRead: Points summarize boxscore offense. A player with many points but low TOI is highly efficient; many points with huge TOI might reflect usage more than dominance.

Name: Shots on Goal
Formula: Count of events where event_type = 'shot' AND event_detail_1 IN ('shot_on_goal', 'goal').
FilterContext: Often filtered to 5v5 for comparability across teams.
Notes: Ignores missed and blocked attempts; more conservative than Corsi/Fenwick.
HowToRead: Think of this as 'pucks that reached the goalie or net'. High shots on goal usually mean the player generates a lot of direct pressure.

Name: Shot Attempts (Corsi Events)
Formula: For a shooter: all events where event_type = 'shot'. For on-ice metrics, sum all shot events for the player’s team while they are on the ice.
FilterContext: Commonly 5v5, score- and venue-adjusted in advanced models.
Notes: Corsi For (CF) and Corsi Against (CA) are the building blocks of many possession metrics.
HowToRead: If CF% is 60%, your team takes 60% of all shot attempts while this player is on the ice. Values above ~50% mean the ice is tilted in your favor during their shifts.

Name: Unblocked Shot Attempts (Fenwick Events)
FilterContext: Same as Corsi; often used as a better proxy for expected goals than pure Corsi.
Notes: Closer proxy to dangerous pressure, since blocked shots rarely become goals.
HowToRead: High Fenwick For and Fenwick% show that when this player is out there, your team is generating unblocked pressure towards the net.

Name: Plus-Minus
Formula: Even-strength goals for while on ice minus even-strength goals against while on ice.
FilterContext: Even strength only, typically 5v5. Often exclude empty-net situations.
Notes: Highly context- and teammate-dependent; noisy over small samples.
HowToRead: Plus-minus is more useful over long samples and in tandem with usage (TOI, QoC, QoT). Negative over a short stretch isn’t automatically bad; look at expected goals and matchups.

Name: Time on Ice (TOI Seconds)
Formula: Sum of shift_duration_seconds from fact_shifts_long for each player/game (or period).
FilterContext: Can be split by EV/PP/PK by filtering on strength fields.
Notes: Key context stat; many other metrics are best interpreted as per-60 rates relative to TOI.
HowToRead: Think of TOI as your 'ice budget'. Players with heavy minutes are trusted; pairing TOI with rates like CF/60 or Points/60 shows efficiency under that workload.

Name: Time on Ice (TOI Minutes)
Notes: Just a more interpretable unit for coaches and broadcasts.
HowToRead: 15–18 EV minutes for a forward often means top-six usage; 22–25 minutes for a defenseman signals top-pair deployment.

Name: Corsi For % (CF%)
Inputs: fact_player_boxscore[corsi_for, corsi_against] or equivalent from on-ice table
FilterContext: Usually 5v5 score-adjusted to compare across teams and states.
Notes: Possession proxy; correlates with future goal differential better than raw goal stats.
HowToRead: Over many games, CF% above ~52–53% suggests positive territorial impact. A player with 60% CF over a season is almost constantly tilting the ice in your favor.

Name: Fenwick For % (FF%)
FilterContext: Similar to CF%; sometimes used as a closer proxy to expected goals.
Notes: Removes blocked shots, so it tracks unblocked danger better than CF%.
HowToRead: FF% tells you what share of unblocked attempts go in your favor with this player on the ice. It’s a strong 'who is driving play' signal over big samples.

Name: Corsi For per 60 (CF/60)
FilterContext: Usually restricted to 5v5; compare players with similar roles.
Notes: Rate version of CF; lets you compare players with different TOI.
HowToRead: If Player A has 65 CF/60 and Player B has 50 CF/60 in similar roles, A drives more shot volume per minute. High CF/60 with tough matchups is especially impressive.

Name: Fenwick For per 60 (FF/60)
Notes: Better aligned with dangerous chances than CF/60 in many models.
HowToRead: High FF/60 indicates the player is on the ice for a lot of unblocked attempts per minute—think sustained pressure and chaos near the net.

Name: Points per 60 (P/60)
FilterContext: Commonly at 5v5, plus separate P/60 for PP usage.
Notes: Key efficiency stat; heavily used in player comps and contract evaluation.
HowToRead: A player with 2.5+ P/60 at 5v5 is elite offensively. Comparing P/60 with CF/60 can differentiate volume shooters from playmakers and finishers.

Name: Rating-Adjusted Corsi For per 60
Level: On-Ice Player-Season / Player-Game (larger samples work better)
FilterContext: Typically 5v5; rating model must be stable.
Notes: Attempts to credit players more when they drive play vs tough competition and discount when they feast on weak opponents.
HowToRead: If two players both have 55 CF/60, but one faced much tougher opponents (higher OppAvgRating), the rating-adjusted CF/60 will highlight that tougher deployment.
